entry.title: RC - day 33
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • architectural whiteboarding
  • mob coding with brownie shots
  • committing the weekend to focus

I was worried the whiteboarding will not go well, as I’ve never done it before and didn’t feel I know enough to answer any questions. I’ve read up on anything I could find on the topic and headed to Turing a bit lightheaded.

The flaw in my reasoning was forgetting that this was RC and the purpose is to learn, not stress. I’ve spent 3 wonderful hours with Bert, Alicia, Ivan and James, going through 5 questions altogether. When we finished I felt a bit dizzy from all the problem solving.

Afterwards, Joe, Cihan and me followed through with the idea of mob coding with enhanced brownies. A few rounds of Malibu with milk later and full of chocolate, we’ve managed to solve a fairly simple graph problem.

I couldn’t stay for the debugging, as today my cat sitting responsibilities started. Both fluffs are keen to play and curious, chasing after anything that moves (even if it doesn’t). Danielle and David’s apartment is full of books on programming and art, with even more fiction, especially of the sf nature. With cats, books and loads of space, it feels like a perfect focused getaway.

entry.title: RC - day 32
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • sleeping in to destress
  • meditating
  • reading up for Friday interview prep
  • had a presentation on learning new skills

Thursday was a presentation day. We’ve had 8 usual evening presentations and 12 non-technical talks, amounting to three hours of learning something new every 5 to 10 minutes.

Three technical talks I enjoyed most were:

  • Satabdi’s Noteranger app for searching her notes
  • Andrea’s great idea for visualising art by style (I’d love to learn more about convolutional neural networks)
  • Marf’s coverage of her two-week spree of exclusively pairing made me want to pair more

The non-technical talks were so diverse it’s really hard to pick favourites, but some of them resonated with me:

  • Alicia’s talk on media literacy and porn consumption was marvelous, I hope she shares her thesis with us (I’ve only managed to find the title Media Literacy for Pornography: Assessing the Impact of an Experimental Curriculum)
  • Sarah’s thoughts on improv inspired me to try it - hope to do it at RC soon
  • Juliano’s description on physiology of singing was cut short, would love to hear more about it (workshop anyone?)
  • Isabel’s presentation on genome editing with CRISPR brought some hopes for the H+ enthusiast in me
  • Taylor guided us rapidly through literary theory
  • James shared some insights on jazz reharmonisation, which makes me want to learn to play guitar properly even more

I’ve had my own non-techical moment on The First 20 Hours book and I’m hoping on writing a proper blog post on it soon and start my first learning experiment next week.

entry.title: RC - day 31
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • taking some time off
  • asking for help when I needed it

Everything is great now.

Wednesday I had a health scare - I fainted on the subway and ended up in a hospital. Nothing much happened, apart from lightly hitting my head on the subway car.

The experience was really stressful because of the insurance. Instead of keeping my cool and being happy someone takes care of me, I was constantly trying to calculate if my travel insurance is going to cover it. That’s a very US experience.

What surprised me is that you get the bill for emergency care about 4-6 weeks after the incident and you actually get three bills:

  • one from the ambulance company, because the ambulances are privately owned
  • one from the hospital
  • one from the doctor that checks you up at the hospital

Altogether an ambulance ride, an ECG & a blood pressure check at the hospital and a two minute chat with the doctor can cost anything between $2.000 and $8.000. Good my insurance is for more than $30.000.

With the Airbnb problems and lack of productivity over the weekend, I felt lost and extremely stressed. Luckily, my loved ones and the RC community were there for me. I decided to take it slow.

entry.title: RC - day 30
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • having a talk with Nancy about my career goals
  • drafting a presentation on learning
  • refactoring my goals and plans

I’ve decided today needs to be a productive day, despite the stress with the Airbnb. Refocusing on growing helped a lot, as did a cold shower from a loved one.

I had a chat with Nancy about my career goals and decided on the next steps I’m going to take in order to improve my professional presence:

  • refactoring some of my older projects that I can quickly improve and use in my portfolio
  • writing long overdue blog posts for my official blog
  • working more on the GitBook, as it is a project with community values in mind
  • looking into remote work opportunities

I’ve also reread a book on acquiring new skills - First 20 Hours by Josh Kaufman - and I’m going to use the concepts to improve my learning over the next few weeks. I also want to have a short presentation on the topic, since it is a system of simple concepts that can be useful to others.

In terms of long-term goals, I’ve revised my bucket, project, learning and productive procrastination lists (I seem to love lists for some reason). I’ve changed some priorities and aligned them more with my programming skills.

entry.title: RC - day 29
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Python
  • getting in touch with Tom to switch apartments
  • getting in touch with Airbnb to cancel my reservation
  • reading some “Gödel, Escher, Bach” and Aaronovitch
  • getting my suitcase to RC

The Internet came back today in the afternoon. Oh, the joy!

I’ve finally got some peace of mind with the apartment situation. Got in touch with Tom and will be staying at his apartment till Oct 3rd. Got in touch with Airbnb and will get a full refund for the remainder of my stay. Got my suitcase to RC from Uptown.

The rest of the day was mostly about reading and chilling, since I didn’t even realise all the Airbnb stuff was so stressful.

The new chill room (Babbage) is perfect for reading and napping and reading some more.

entry.title: RC - day 28
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • almost getting banana coffee
  • helping with RC space rearrangements
  • chilling with Ginger and a book

Yes, there was still no Internet. I’ve had a plan for that - going for a banana coffee in Brooklyn.

First I had a total derp moment with swiping my Metrocard and not passing fast enough. So I decided to walk to the nearest bookstore, but it was closed. Apparently, the city never sleeps, but the books need some rest.

The Internet was down also in the bank, so I walked and got lost a few times to withdraw some cash. Then I took the subway to Brooklyn, where the J+B cafe I wanted to get my banana coffee at was closed.

I took it surprisingly well and just went for a walk through Brooklyn, took the wrong subway, walked some more in Lower Manhattan and ended up at a Korean cafe for misugaru latte.

Got back to the RC. Had fun with Lisa, John and Cihran rearranging the space a little bit. Ended the day with blissful hours of reading and cuddling with Ginger.

This post is late due to, surprise-surprise, no Internet :)

entry.title: Downtown train
entry.content:
I wanted to learn algorithms, but Internet was down.

I went for a banana coffee, but the cafe was closed.

So instead I just walked most of the weekend, through Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn.

click an image to see the gallery
entry.summary: I wanted to learn algorithms, but Internet was down.

entry.title: Curiouser and curiouser
entry.content:
• If you swipe your Metrocard and don’t pass fast enough, you’ll have to wait 15 minutes to use it again at the same station. At least I get to walk a lot to the next station.
  • The subway always has some changes in routes, times and entrances. You’ll most probably learn about them after waiting 40+ minutes on the wrong station.
  • It must be really hard to be in a wheelchair here. I can’t imagine using public transport or most of the sidewalks.
  • If you never felt race is an issue (and being Polish makes it highly improbable), you will feel very <insert your skin colour here>. It is somehow very important in NYC (and maybe even in the US in general). I look white and American until I start speaking. They’re generally much nicer when they notice my accent.
  • Amazon probably won’t accept you European debit card if you want to use it with a Polish address. Or any address. They just don’t want my money.
  • Second-hand awkwardness is almost guaranteed, if you’re not used to people randomly singing/dancing/talking to you in public.

click an image to see the gallery

The subway always has some changes in routes, times and entrances. You’ll most probably learn about them after waiting 40+ minutes on the wrong station. It must be really hard to be in a wheelchair here. I can’t imagine using public transport or most of the sidewalks. If you never felt race is an issue (and being Polish makes it highly improbable), you will feel very <insert your skin colour here>. It is somehow very important in NYC (and maybe even in the US in general). I look white and American until I start speaking. They’re generally much nicer when they notice my accent. Amazon probably won’t accept you European debit card if you want to use it with a Polish address. Or any address. They just don’t want my money. Second-hand awkwardness is almost guaranteed, if you’re not used to people randomly singing/dancing/talking to you in public.

entry.title: RC - day 27
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • building a simple 52/17 timer
  • reading random books
  • staying positive

Plague prevailed and spread - there was no Internet today neither at RC, nor at the Airbnb. Funny how easy it is to forget how often I use it. And how safe it makes me feel. With the ability to contact my loved ones any time I want, I haven’t really felt far from home up till now.

I decided to make an exercise on patience out of it. I’ve been doing everything I could without Internet, untilI really needed it - mostly to check my email and organise a new apartment.

Lessons learned:

  • share your grapes (literal grapes, when you buy 2+ lbs)
  • pick up random books that look fun
  • add pumpkin spice to your morning coffee before you pour hot water in
  • breathe
  • if someone offers to share their data plan - use it for the sake of your sanity (thank you V!)
  • chocolate soothes all stress

I’ve created a simple 52/17 timer (52 minutes for work, 17 minutes playtime), since Fokasu has irritating advertisements and it was a good exercise on programming without Internet. Never thought simple JavaScript can take so much time.

I also read two books I randomly picked in the library, based entirely on their covers:

  • Happier by Tal Ben-Shahar, with a lot of ideas on how to improve your happiness and a few exercises I’ve added to my productive procrastination list

  • If Hemingway Wrote JavaScript by Angus Croll, a hilarious little book on how different writers would write JavaScript programs - my favourites were:

    Ernest Hemigway on returning the first n numbers of the Fibonacci sequence:

    1 function fibonacci(size) {
2
3 var first = 0, second = 1, next, count = 2,
  result = [first, second];
4
5 if (size < 2)
6 return "the request was made but it was not good"
7
8 while (count++ < size) {
9 next = first + second;
10 first = second;
11 second = next;
12 result.push(next);
13 }
14
15 return result;
16 }

    Jack Kerouac on returning the factorial of the supplied argument:

    1 /*...the only numbers for me are the mad ones,
  take forty-three like a steam
  engine with a talky caboose at the end*/ n = 43, /
  *and that lanky fellow in a cocked fedora*/ r = 1 /
  *then back to our number, our mad number,
  mad to become one*/ while (n > 1) /
  *mad to descend*/ n--, /
  *mad to multiply*/ r = r * n /
  *and at the end, you see the blue center-light pop,
  and everybody goes 1.4050061177528801e+51...*/
2 r

    Douglas Adams on returning all the prime numbers up to the supplied argument:

    1 //Here I am, brain the size of a planet,
  and they ask me to write JavaScript...
2 function kevinTheNumberMentioner(_){
3 l=[]
4 /* mostly harmless --> */ with(l) {
5
6 //Sorry about all this,
  my babel fish has a headache today...
7 for (ll=!+[]+!![];ll<_+(+!![]);ll++) {
8 lll=+!![];
9 while (ll%++lll);
10 //I've got this terrible pain
  in all the semicolons down my right-hand side.
11 (ll==lll)&&push(ll);
12 }
13 forEach(alert);
14
15 }
16
17 //You're really not going to like this...
18 return [!+[]+!+[]+!+[]+!+[]]+[!+[]+!+[]];
19 }

I wanted to end the day on a positive note, so I got creative on the whiteboard.

Thankfully, the Internet works at the apartment, at least for now.

entry.title: RC - day 26
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Python
  • read up a lot about regex
  • did a tiny project in p5.js

It’s very hard to find an affordable room in NYC, especially with the stress of running from cockroaches ASAP.

It’s much easier when you have Eva & Shawn as a part of your family and a community of Recursers.

Airbnb agreed to a full refund on my remaining stay at the apartment, so I’ve spent most of the day looking for an affordable and clean room. As it turns out, it’s not easy (unless your definition of affordable and/or clean is more flexible). I turned to my community and got offered so much help the stress magically disappeared.

As the day was mostly focused on the mundane, I took two small steps to be a better programmer:

  • read a great article on prime number checking regex shared by Juan (and went into a wild regex learning spiral)
  • did my first project in p5.js thanks to Emily’s instructions

Hopefully by the end of the weekend I’ll have a new place to sleep and thus be able to create even more.

In the evening a tragic thing happened to all of us - Internet connection stopped working at the RC and we all had to go home before midnight. Let’s hope this disaster passes with the new day rising.
